div.p: 1. V: symbols 40. symbols 1. symbols Sun rose 5:9.
Heard Little— Psalm 139.37. Read Johnson’s Sermon 2. on Repentance.
Baker 1. Timothy 5.22. “Neither be partaker of other men’s sins.”
Read Colman. Sermon 7. Christianity a rule of life.

Evening Heard Little. Luke 8.18. “Take heed therefore how ye hear; for whosoever hath, to him shall be given: and whosoever hath not, from him shall be taken, even that which he seemeth to have.” Met Mr Gold of Boston at Church. He had called yesterday when I was engaged and could not see him— He goes for Boston, tomorrow morning.
2. V. symbols 2.3. symbols

list.item: Baker D. came to make enquiries concerning the operation of the Land Laws. Pays in part for his house by a Land grant in Indiana— Enquires if there should appear a prior grantee of the land, would the U.S. indemnify the second— I believe so but could not answer with certainty— Sutton’swife’s dower is also to be renounced.
Elgar Commissioner of Public buildings. Came to speak of the designs entered for the premium, for the tympanum of the Capitol— Spoke also of the Repairs upon the Presidential House

list.head: of the Navy— These Officers are here, for the Court of Enquiry, upon the conduct of Captain David Porter, in the hostile invasion of the Island of Porto-Rico, at Foxardo in Novr. last; and concerning the transportation of specie, by the squadron under his command. They came merely for a visit

list.item: Clay. H. Is preparing the Instructions for R. King as Envoy to Great-Britain. Upon the Colonial Trade question; thinks there is more than plausibility in the British claims, and that we ought to concede something on this point.— Case of H. Lee.

list.head:
Judges, Clerk, Marshal, and Lawyers, attending, the Circuit Court of the District of Columbia; now commencing at Washington, for the County; came for a visit.
Mema.
F. C. Hall applies for an appointment in the Marine Corps.
M. L. Hill— The investigation of his conduct, at the time of the Embargo; again demanded by individuals—
School of Artillery practice?
Mr Clay spoke of the appointment of H. Lee, by the Postmaster Genl.

div.p: 3. V. symbols 4.5 symbols
Southard S.N. read me Captain Porter’s paper delivered to the Court of Enquiry; objecting to the Court because composed of officers, two of the three his juniors; and the answer.
Brent. D. My note for him at U.S. Branch Bank payable— Took it up and took his note.
Partridge Captain—came with twelve of his Cadets: among whom two sons of John Hancock of Boston—Grandsons of Ebenr Hancock.
Baker, Daniel and Mr Sutton— Took four Notes of Mr Baker. He took the Deed, to have it recorded— D. Brent’s deed of trust to secure me had also remained, not recorded.
Call on James Barbour S.W. confined to his house with a boil on his cheek.
G— Sullivan here this Evening.
4. V:30. symbols 6.7 symbols

Woodward A. B. is going to Detroit—wishes another appointment.— Spoke much of the project for establishing a Home-Department; which I thought could be accomplished only at a change of administration— He is an intelligent, learned and public spirited man, with defective judgment; and so strange in his dress and deportment, that he passes with many for insane—and is within a thin partition of it in reality.
Balch Dr of Georgetown, called and introduced, Revd. Mr Nevins of Baltimore.
Deherty— Mrs came to petition for the release from prison of her brother, a youth named Blanford in jail for an assault and battery in some brawl.

Southard S.N. with proceedings of Court Martials, upon Sailing Master Jacob Mull, sentenced to be dismissed from the Navy, which I approved—upon Landon N. Carter to be reprimanded by the Secretary of the Navy; and upon Midshipman Van Dyke, to be dismissed from the Navy, which I did not approve— Southard questioned whether a Court Martial had power to direct, that the Secretary of the Navy should reprimand an Officer— It is doubtless optional with him to comply with the direction or not; and I advised him to ascertain the usage and act accordingly.
Teackle— Littleton Dennis— Applies for the appointment of Consul at Rio de Janeiro.

Clay. H.— preparing Instructions for R. King— Proposes postponing most of them, till after he returns from Kentucky— And to prepare now only those relating to the Slave indemnity Commission— By the strange conduct of the British Commissioner Jackson this Commission is now brought to a stand and have adjourned till December. The fifth Auditor S. Pleasonton, sent me papers of recommendation for several keepers of Lights— I directed the appointment of Joseph Dixon as keeper of the floating Light, Pamptico Sound, North-Carolina.

Watkins. T. came from Jeremy Robinson, to request that I would see him— I said I could scarcely refuse to see any man: but it would be useless for him to see me, unless he could remove the charges against his character, of which I had information from Salem— Watkins spoke also of the appointment by the Postmaster of H. Lee, with much dissatisfaction. These visitors kept me constantly occupied, from immediately after breakfast till 5. O’Clock— I took my daily walk, after dinner— Passed an hour at Bagatelle—
5. V:30. symbols 8.9. symbols

Southard S.N. With the Sentences in the Court-Martials on Lieutt. Carter and Midshipman Van Dyke: Southard has given the reprimand to Carter according to the Sentence
Sentence of the Court-martial. He told me that Captain Angus was here, and had been with him last Evening.
Nourse— Joseph, Register of the Treasury, called with Mr Gallaudet and Benjn Rittenhouse—both employed in the Registers Office.

Angus, late Captain came again upon his application for reinstatement in the Navy. I had both in his and in Isaac Phillips’s case decided that I had no Constitutional power to restore to his rank and employment an Officer; dismissed from the service by one of my Predecessor’s— Angus appealed powerfully to my sympathy— Said he had no other means of subsistence— Asked me to nominate him anew to the Senate, and in the meantime give him an acting appointment as Captain— He would take rank at the bottom of the list, rather than lose every thing. I came with Angus from Gothenburg to the Texel, and have for him a kind personal feeling— But I could neither restore nor renominate him— His state of mind is not suitable for a new appointment, and would disqualify him for responsible active Service— I advised him to consult his friends whether it would be advisable for him to apply to Congress, and told him I believed his best course would be to apply for a pension— I had no doubt he would be entitled to one equal to half-pay for life.

Clay— H came with a Quaker named Barnes of Barnesville, Ohio, who brought several memorials with numerous signatures, requesting an alteration in the direction of the projected continuation of the Cumberland road— Barnes wishes it to pass through the place of his residence which bears his name; and argued his cause with earnestness. He will see me again to-morrow, and in the meantime call on the Secy of War— Mr Clay came again, and expressed the wish to go next week on his visit to Kentucky; to bring his family here. I desired him to have a Commission made out for Philip C. Pendleton, as judge of the Western District of Virginia— I received a Letter from R. King mentioning that he had engaged a conditional passage for England; to sail the first of June— His Instructions for the present will be principally upon the Slave indemnity.
Brown; brought a Petition from Benson M’Kenney, confined in jail for an assault and battery; to be released— I told him he must first obtain a certificate from the judges.
Hellen Johnson came from Rockville.— Hours walk with G. Sullivan, after dinner. Bagatelle— T. B. Johnson, Mrs Frye, and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, Evening here. Chess with W. S. Smith.—
6. V:45. Sun risen. symbols 10 symbols 11. symbols

Southard. S.N. With the proceedings of the Court of Inquiry, upon the first charge against Porter. He Protests against the competency of the Court; a majority of its members being Officers, his juniors. Mr Southard said Angus had gone off this morning for New-York. But last Evening his Deportment at his lodgings had been so wild, and his menaces of murder against Mr Southard so marked, that Southard received a warning to be upon his guard, and keep him at a distance— He has repeatedly uttered similar threats; and at one time Southard went armed for several days, to be prepared for self-defence
self-defence— He cannot in any manner be restored usefully to the service.

Barbour S.W. Claims of rank by Major Lomax and Captain Baker— The former considered as settled by the last Administration— Lomax contends that the decision was illegal—his argument is founded on a variation of phraseology in the Acts of 1815 and 1821. There is plausibility in his claim but perhaps nothing more. In Baker’s case Mr Barbour thought there was nothing to be done, but to correct the Register mis-statement of the date of his Commission. I told Mr Barbour, I inclined to think that proposals should be issued for the supplies of Ordnance, without admitting the exclusive pretensions of the three founderies from which all the purchases had been made of late years.

Barnes the quaker brought a map of the road from St. Clairsville to Worcester, Ohio, to shew that the new road ought to pass through Barnesville— He admits it will increase the distance about a mile in forty, but thinks nearly the whole of that mile can be regained by shortenings at two places on the way— Barbour asked him what would be the opinion of Mr Ruggles the Senator from Ohio, who resides in that neighbourhood— He said Ruggles would say nothing. I asked him what would be the opinion of the people residing on the other road. He said they would doubtless object to the change, but not with reason— He told me that at the recent election he had voted for Clay, because he had pledged himself for him here at Washington, two years ago. but that his Sons had voted for me.
Masi— a youth of 16. applies for a Midshipman’s warrant. Thought I knew him.
Brent— D. came to enquire what Commission should be given to J. J. Appleton for his mission to Naples— I said that of a special agent for claims.
Doane Isaiah— Applies for appointment as Captain of a Revenue Cutter to be built.
Macomb, General—introduced Coll Lawrence of Second Regiment of Infantry.
Lee— William, just returned from an excursion to Philadelphia.

Elgar— Commissioner of the Public Buildings; brought me a Letter, requesting me to decide upon the designs which have been presented for a bas-relief in the tympanum of the Capitol, for which a premium of 500 dollars was offered by advertisement in the Newspapers— I said I would in two or three days call at the Capitol and see them— Elgar said the Comptroller had agreed to pass the account for cleaning the House before we came in to it.

Southard S.N. again in the Evening. Captain Porter, after protesting against the Court of Enquiry, as incompetent and withdrawing from it, this morning sent to Mr Southard, a number of papers relating to his transactions at Foxardo—apparently with the intention that they should be laid before the Court— Southard said Mr Clay’s opinion was that he ought to return the papers to Porter, declining to receive them and lay them before a Court, before which Porter himself refused to attend. Southard said his own impression had been to receive and transmit them without comment to the Court. My first Sentiment
Sentiment coincided with that of Mr Clay, but on reflection, I thought it best to make no points with Captain Porter, not absolutely indispensable, and to give him every possible advantage of trial— There are also a number of papers received at the Department of State from the Charge d’Affaires of Spain Salmon, translations of which Mr Southard left with me, and is to call again to-morrow Morning.
7. VI. Sun-risen symbols 12 symbols 13 symbols
Brent— Daniel— came to enquire of the hour for a cabinet Meeting proposed—2. O’Clock fixed.

Southard S.N. I returned him the papers received from Mr Salmon, against Captain Porter’s proceedings at Foxardo, which together with those received yesterday from Porter himself are to be transmitted to the Court of Inquiry— I gave him also the draft of a decision disapproving the Sentence of the Court Martial on Midshipman Van Dyke.
Keeper of Light-House on Cape Florida. John Du Bose to be appointed. Salary 400 a year.
Keeper of Light House on Petit Manan—Robert Leighton—both recommended by Pleasonton.
Judge of Western District of Virginia—Philip C. Pendleton—Temporary Commission.
Keeper of Floating-light on Carysfort reef Florida—John Whalton, with 700 a year.
Bath in Potowmack river; about 10 minutes at Noon— First of the Season.

Scott Alexander, for place; with a recommendation from Judge Washington—and renews an old application for an additional allowance; for an agency at Caraccas in 1813— Says Poinsett had an additional allowance made to him— I referred him to the Department of State.

Cabinet Meeting at 2. Clay, Barbour and Southard present. Wirt absent at Baltimore. Barnes and the continuation of the Cumberland road— Clay strongly adverse to any change. Several Letters and remonstrances received against Barnes’s application. Congress of American Ministers at Panama. Question whether the United States will be represented there. Clay and Barbour decidedly in favour of it— Southard suggests objections but acquiesces. Salazar and Obregon to be answered that we accede generally to the proposal, but think that the meeting cannot be held so early as next October— Time will be necessary for arranging and agreeing upon the objects of Negotiation and modes of proceeding— Critical condition of the Island of Cuba— Fisheries— A vessel to be stationed for their protection, on the Coast of Maine, and New-Brunswick— A garrison also to be stationed in Maine; to preserve the timber on the contested territory from depredation. Govr Barbour Secy of War to write concerning it to the Governor of Maine— Southard brought the papers relating to the investigation of the conduct of M. L. Hill, Collector at Bath. The persons appointed for the investigation— Ez. Whitman, Judge Ware, and Burleigh.
8. V. symbols 14. symbols 15.

Heard Little. 2. Thessalonians 1.11.12. [“]Wherefore also we pray always for you, that our God would count you worthy of this calling, and fulfil all the good pleasure of his goodness and the work of faith with power:— That the name of our Lord Jesus Christ may be glorified in you, and ye in him, according to the grace of our God and of the Lord Jesus Christ.”
Read Colman’s Sermon 8—On the Bible Society Distributions.
Heard Baker. Romans 5.20— “Moreover the law entered, that the offence might abound. But where sin abounded grace did much more abound.”— Contrast of sin and grace.
Read Johnson’s Sermon 3. On the fear of God, and hardness of heart.
Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us.

Heard Little. Acts 10.34.35. “Then Peter opened his mouth, and said, Of a truth I perceive that God is no respecter of persons:— But in every nation he that feareth him, and worketh righteousness, is accepted with him.” A strong text for the doctrine of justification by works—which the preacher maintained accordingly.

On returning home, found as visitors, S. L. Gouverneur, from New-York, who is going with Hortensia Hay to Mr Monroe’s at Oakhill— Mr and Mrs G. Sullivan, who are going to visit Mr Jefferson and Mr Madison— Mr Tench Ringgold the Marshal.
9. IV:45. symbols 5 symbols 16 symbols Azazel. 17. symbols

Bernhard Button maker from Baltimore with a singing child Ann Eliza Davis— He wants to remove to this place; a loan of money and a small Office. His button manufactory does not succeed at Baltimore, even with the help of subscriptions— But the child sung to me at his bidding a Latin an English and a German Song. I told him there would be still less prospect of success for his button making here than at Baltimore
Order that John Blanchard confined for an assault, be released from prison—

Lee— Richard B. recommending Edward S. Lewis, as a Justice of the Peace, for the County of Washington; and soliciting a place as Suttler at Norfolk, which though not very dignified he said he understood was lucrative—or any other suitable office.
Force. P. to bind 2 Volumes of Laws and furnish parchment.
Signed the disapprobation of the Sentence of the Court-martial upon Midshipman Van Dyke.

Rode with John to the City Hall, and Capitol, where I inspected the designs for the Tympanum of the Capitol—none of which were satisfactory, or appeared to be deserving of the premium offered— Mr Elgar and Mr Bulfinch proposed to send them to my house, to which I assented— Walk home. symbols 3 symbols
10. V. Sunrise. symbols 18. symbols 19. symbols

Southard S.N. brought the Report of the Court of enquiry upon the first of the two charges against Captain Porter— The invasion of the Island of Porto-Rico at Foxardo. The Inquiry upon the second charge, a neglect of duty, for the transportation of Specie was instituted at the request of Captain Porter himself. And he having withdrawn, and protested against the competency of the Court, they left it undecided whether they were to pursue the Inquiry upon the second charge. Southard proposed to discharge them from the former precept, but to send them another precept to assemble again at the same time and place and enquire and report upon the matter of the second charge. I thought it would be better merely to direct the Court to proceed to the inquiry concerning the second charge, under the original precept.

Graham— George. returned from his visit to Kentucky— I asked him to send me from the Land Office, a minute of all the Land-grants in Blank, and hereafter a minute of the numbers in which they may be disposed of. The practice of signing an indefinite number of all public documents, as Patents, Land-grants and Commissions has its inconveniences and dangers— I must confine it within narrow limits, and require the return to me of every blank signed by me and not issued.
Persico, the Sculptor, brought to my house the design model for the tympanum at the Capitol. the other models and designs were also brought, and set up in the unfurnished long room.

Barbour. S.W. came with the new Volume of Army Regulations compiled by General Scott, and declared by Mr Monroe to be in force— He brought also the remonstrance of the proprietor of the foundery in Virginia in which Mr Wirt is concerned, against issuing a notice, inviting a competition of proposals for supplying ordinance— And

Mason, Genl. John came to plead the cause of his foundery at Georgetown, upon the same argument—a pledge being alledged to have been given by the Government, to employ his foundery. Letters from Mr Monroe when Secy of State, and from Commodore Rodgers, as President of the Navy Board are produced promising employment, for a time, but that has past. Mason spoke also of the proceedings and suspension of the Slave indemnity Commission; being an Agent for many of the Claimants.

Clay S.S. came with Mr Bailey the person who was sent in February 1815 immediately after the ratification of the Treaty of Peace to recover the Slaves that were at Tangier Island, but without success. He now lives in Washington County Maryland, and Mr Clay sent for him that he might give particular information respecting that transaction— Mr Clay left with me also a draught of Instructions to H. Middleton, directing him to urge upon the Russian Government their immediate recognition of the South-American Governments, and their good Offices to prevail upon Spain to make the same recognition— The principal argument is derived from the critical condition of the Islands of Cuba and Porto-Rico: the high interest that Spain has to retain the possession of them, which would be entirely satisfactory to us; and the danger that she may lose them if the war should continue much longer. We
We had company to dine. Joseph Anderson, James Barbour, Barrell. William Brent, Henry Clay, Coxe, William Cranch, Nathl Frye, George Graham, Richard Harrison, Genl. T. S. Jesup, Coll. Roger Jones, Walter Jones, B. L. Lear, John M’Lean, Genl A. Macomb, Joseph Nourse, Dr Pendleton, Tench Ringgold, Coll. Isaac Roberdeau, Genl. Winfield Scott, W. S. Smith, Samuel L. Southard, Thomas Swann, Buckner Thruston and Thomas T. Tucker— There had been invitations to Genl. Brown, ColsGibson and Lawrence Captains Bainbridge, Ballard, Chauncey, Crane, Dallas, Finch, Jones, Morris, Read, and Tingey of the Navy, Mr T. B. Johnson, Judge Morsell, and Mr Wirt the Attorney General, who sent excuses or were absent from the City.
Solitary walk before dinner.—
11. IV:45. symbols 20 symbols 21 symbols
Mrs. Adams went this morning with Mr and Mrs Frye to Baltimore; to attend the wedding of Ann Buchanan, with Lieutenant Wade.
Signed Commissions to Richard Rush, as Secretary of the Treasury. dated 7. March
Rufus King, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Great-Britain. dated 5. May.
John Alsop King— Secretary to the Legation to Great Britain. dated 5. May.
The Commission for Mr Rufus King sent me to sign had omitted the limitation to the end of the next Session of the Senate— I sent for Mr Brent and directed its insertion.

Clay— H— here and proposed that copies of the Instructions to H. Middleton, concerning Spain and South America (to which I agreed,) should be furnished to Mr R. King and Mr Brown, our Ministers at London and Paris— I fixed for to-morrow 2. O’Clock the Cabinet Meeting on the Report of the Court of Inquiry, in the case of Captain D. Porter.
12. IV:45. Sun rose 4.58. symbols 22 symbols 23 symbols
Sewall, left a paper of solicitation for donations to the library of the Cony female academy at Augusta Maine.

Mr Wigglesworth is a Son of Thomas Wigglesworth, of Boston, and Grandson of Dr Edward Wigglesworth, Professor of Divinity, and at whose house I boarded during a winter vacation when I was at the University— He is going to Richmond with the two persons whose names I lost.
Mr Southard introduced Mr H to me as his wife’s brother.
Major Burd is the Commanding Officer at Annapolis, and going thither.

Young Watkins brought me a Letter from his father. He is going to England with views to a commercial Establishment. Wishes the appointment of Consul or Consular agent at Manchester— He asked a Letter to the Consul at Liverpool, Maury which I declined giving, but said I supposed Mr Clay would give him one.
Mr Fowler of Newport Rhode Island came with Mr Cazenove of Alexandria.
Coll. Lawless of Missouri, introduced by Mr Clay, brought me a Letter of introduction from Thomas H. Benton the Senator from that State.
Cabinet Meeting, on Report of the Court of Inquiry upon the conduct of Captn. Porter— Present Clay S.S. Barbour S.W. Southard S.N. Absent. Wirt. A.G.

It was determined that Porter should be tried by a Court martial for the affair at Foxardo; against the opinion of Southard who thought the Executive should pass a direct censure upon him— He was distrustful of the decision of naval Officers upon the case— Apprehensive they would justify him in the face of the merits of the affair— I said I had not that distrust— I believed they would do their duty, however unpleasant it might be— They would themselves be under responsibility to their Oaths, to the Country and to the World. But whatever their sentence might be the executive will have done his duty— The trial will have been according to the Laws of the Land and of Nations— The accused will have had secured to him the benefit of a trial by his peers, and all the advantages which the law could secure to him— Mr Clay and Governor Barbour were both decidedly of the same opinion. Southard suggested the difficulty of forming a Court martial, especially with a majority of its members Senior in Commission to Porter— There are but seven Captains his seniors on the list; and of these Rodgers and Hull are absent, Stewart is upon trial himself, Chauncey sat on the Court of Enquiry, Bainbridge has expressed an unfavourable opinion of the transaction, and is thus disqualified to sit, and there are grave exceptions against both Barron and Tingey— Still a Court martial must be preferred to either of the other alternatives; of receiving the report of the Court of Inquiry, taking no other step; or of passing censure by a mere arbitrary executive Act— The Court Martial however is not to be instituted, till the Court of Inquiry shall have reported upon the second Charge, of which Southard said he had no doubt that Porter would be honourably acquitted; and that the result would redound to the credit of the Navy— Johnson Hellen returned this day to Rockville.
13. IV:45. Sunrose 4–57. symbols 24. symbols 25 symbols

I place in the margin the names of the persons who called upon me in the course of the day— Mr Keene brought a Letter of recommendation from Humphrey Peake of Alexandria; and applies for the appointment of Navy Agent at Pensacola. Dr Thornton called to visit me on his recovery from a severe illness— Mr Clay took leave, and departs to-morrow upon his tour home; to fetch his family— He asked me how long I would give him permission of absence; I told him at his own discretion; being sure that he would not lengthen it without necessity; and understanding of course that in case of any sudden emergency requiring his presence here, we could give him timely notice of it. He said he expected to return with his family about the middle of July— He had sent me a Letter to him from W. Brent, member of the House from Louisiana, strongly urging the removal of Sterret the Naval Officer at New-Orleans, as a noisy and clamorous reviler
reviler of the administration, who was concerned in a project of some worthless persons like himself to insult Brent, when he passed through New-Orleans at the Theatre, for his vote at the Election—which project however failed. And Brent’s Letter says that a vast majority of the people of Louisiana, are entirely satisfied with the election— Mr Clay also urged the removal of Sterret, and observed that with regard to the conduct of persons holding Offices at the pleasure of the President, the course of the administration should be to avoid on the one hand political persecution; and on the other an appearance of pusillanimity. That so long as the election was pending, every man was free to indulge his preference for any of the Candidates, but after it was decided no officer depending upon the will of the President for his place, should be permitted to hold a conduct in open and continual disparagement of the Administration and its head— I said these principles were undoubtedly correct; but there was some difficulty and great delicacy in the application of them to individuals. If the charge could be specifically brought home to Sterret of having concerted or countenanced a purpose of public insult to a member of Congress for the honest and independent discharge of his duty, I would not hesitate to remove such a black guard as unworthy of holding any public trust, whatever— But Mr Brent only mentions this as a design of Sterret’s, never carried into execution— And as a design it could scarcely be susceptible of proof. Should I remove Sterret by a mere executive fiat—he would consider himself injured and immediately demand the cause of his removal— To answer merely that it was the pleasure of the President, would be harsh and odious—inconsistent with the principle upon which I have commenced the Administration, of removing no person from Office, but for cause, and would lead to the inference that I was ashamed to assign the real cause— That real cause, an intention never carried into act, would scarcely justify the removal of a man from office in the public opinion— It would be thought to indicate an irritable, hasty, and vindictive temper; and give rise to newspaper discussions of which all the disadvantage would fall upon the Administration— Besides, should I remove this man for this cause, it must be upon some fixed principle, which would apply to others as well as to him. And where was it possible to draw the line? Of the custom house Officers throughout the union, four-fifths in all probability were opposed to my election— There were now all in my power, and I had been urged very earnestly and from various quarters to sweep away my opponents, and provide with their places for my friends— I can justify the refusal to adopt this policy, only by the steadiness and consistency of my adhesion to my own— If I depart from this in one instance, I shall be called upon by my friends to do the same in many: an invidious and inquisitorial scrutiny into the personal dispositions of public officers, will creep through the whole union, and the most selfish and sordid passions will be kindled into activity to distort the conduct and misrepresent the feelings of men, whose places may become the prize of Slander upon them— Mr Clay did not press the subject any farther—

Mr Charles Sigourney resides at Hartford, Connecticut, and is the Son, of one of my earliest acquaintances; whom I knew at Amsterdam in 1780. He now brought me Letters of Introduction
Introduction from Josiah Quincy the Mayor of Boston, and from Edward Cruft. He is here on an excursion for health and pleasure, with his wife, who was a Miss Huntly, an accomplished Lady and authoress— Mr Forrest came to urge for a Letter from me to President Boyer of Hayti, in behalf of Mr Oliver of Baltimore; and also to recommend Mr Hammett the Consul at Naples for some appointment in pursuit of the claims— I told him Mr Monroe had deliberately decided against writing to Boyer, because it would be an acknowledgment of his Government: and I could not, at least so soon reverse this decision— Hammett he says was educated at the expense of the State of Maryland.

row.cell: H. B. Chew as Vice Consul of Mexico

div.p: Mrs. Adams returned this Evening from Baltimore.
14. V. symbols 26. symbols 27. symbols
Announced himself as a Revolutionary Officer of Washington County Maryland—he had been here yesterday—then and now symbols
Hodgson is going for a few weeks into the Country.

Burr asks a suspension of the appointment of judge Grant, as Collector at Oswego, and recommends Joseph Easton. Says he knows both well— That Grant was his partner in Law practice one year was of intemperate habits, and doubtful integrity— Gave an account of the mode of smuggling upon the Lakes, and said if an honest and vigilant collector should be appointed at Oswego, the return of revenue would be doubled within one year, from that place.

Mr Teackle came to renew his application for an appointment abroad; and told me he was going to pass a few weeks at Philadelphia— Weightman the Mayor of this City came with a Resolution of the Corporation to raise 40000 dollars by Lottery—10.000 dollars for each of the years 1822. 3. 4. and 5. The approbation of the Presidents to the act, is necessary for its validity, and I had doubts upon the Construction of the Law. It is the Act of incorporation of the City of 15. May 1820. and provides that not more than ten thousand dollars shall be raised by Lottery in one year— Mr Weightman said there was a precedent, sanctioned by Mr Madison, when President, which I desired him to send me. I told him I should take the opinion of the Attorney-General, on the construction of the Law; and he said the Corporation would also consult their Counsel— Mr Graham brought me a list of the Land-grants signed by me, remaining at the Land-Office— Mentioned the propriety of appointing a Register at Cahaba; and the disposal of the Choctaw School-fund. The Power of acting for the President was heretofore given to the Secretary of War. Mr Southard by a Note asked for my decision upon the appointment of Grant as Collector at Oswego— I sent for him, and told him of the information given me by Burr; upon which without much relying upon it, I concluded to suspend the appointment, and let Grant be informed, that I considered Sage’s Letter as not a positive resignation: without which I should
should not make the appointment: and that there had been presented to me, objections to the appointment of Grant himself— The Court of enquiry upon Captain Porter is still sitting; and Mr Southard again expressed his belief that with regard to the transportation of specie Porter’s conduct would be fully justified.

Mr Barbour had intelligence from his father who is convalescent. He spoke of a Mexican expedition against Cuba— Then of the very critical state of affairs between the State of Georgia and the Creek Indians. Brought me a Letter from the Agent Crowell, of 27. April, complaining of the Governor of Georgia. Mr Barbour said he would make a Report upon the question of Rank between Generals Gaines and Scott. The correspondence between those officers was extremely acrimonious. Mr Barbour’s opinion coincides with that of General Brown; decisively in favour of Gaines— The question ought to have been decided by the last Administration; but it was evaded by Mr Calhoun, on the pretence that it was merely an abstract question! Scott however produced a private Letter from Calhoun to him, written when it was expected that the command of the army would be vacated by the decease of Genl. Brown, and promising it in that event to Scott— Judge Grant came with a petition from Inhabitants of Sodus for appointment of Ishmael D. Hill as Light-house keeper, and with solicitations for himself as Collector at a Oswego— Says it is his only subsistence— I told him the appointment would not be made till Mr Sage should have positively resigned.
I renewed the attempt to Journalize morning and evening—
15. V:15 symbols 1. symbols 2 symbols

These four Creek Indians called on me this morning before breakfast, with a Letter from Govr. Troup of Georgia, and a talk sent by him to certain other Creek Chiefs— The Letter which is in a style similar to that which the same personage used with Mr Monroe, announced to me the murder of the Chief called General Mackintosh, which was confirmed by Chilly who narrowly escaped himself with his life. It was on Saturday the 30th. of last month—that a party of about 400 surrounded, and set fire to his house, and killed him, and another chief his next door neighbour— Troup charges Crowell the Agent with having instigated this massacre, and vows revenge, with a Spirit as ferocious as ever inspired any Creek Indian— I told Chilly that I was deeply distressed at these melancholy tidings, and would do all that would be in my power for him: advising him to call upon the Secretary at War to-morrow— I stopped myself at his house as I was going to Church, and he being gone out, left the papers with word that I would call again after Church— Heard Little 1. Corinthians 12.25: “That there should be no schism in the body.” from the purport of the discourse I should suppose there was some misunderstanding within his own congregation, or between him and them. I asked Mr Charles Bulfinch to call at my house at Noon to-morrow. I again called at Governor Barbour’s house, and found him at home; deeply affected at
at the intelligence from Georgia; thinking Governor Troup a madman, and very apprehensive of opposition— I desired him to confer with these Indians to-morrow morning; ascertain what they wished to have done; what disposable force may be directed to the threatened part of Georgia; and what answer should be given to Govr Troup.— At home I read Colman Sermon 9. upon the progress and prospects of the Gospel; then heard a Stranger at Mr Baker’s from Acts 13.38.39. “Be it known unto you therefore, men and brethren, that through this man is preached unto you the forgiveness of sins:— And by him all that believe are justified from all things, from which ye could not be justified by the Law of Moses.” Here again was justification by faith— Read before and after dinner Johnson’s Sermon 4. upon Charity; an occasional discourse delivered at Bath— Heard Little again in the Evening from Luke 13.20.21. “And again he said, whereunto shall I liken the kingdom of God?— It is like leaven, which a woman took and hid in three measures of meal, till the whole was leavened.” On returning home I found at my door G. Sullivan just back from his visits to Mr Jefferson and Mr Madison— Dr and Mrs Thornton were also visiting at my house.
16. V. symbols 3. symbols 4 symbols Cloud and fog.

Dr Watkins and Niles came to recommend Simonton for the appointment of consular commercial agent at the Havana, vacated by the death of John Warner last Friday— Niles was peculiarly urgent; upon the expectation that Mr Simonton would apply the emoluments of the office for the benefit of Mr Warner’s family; said to be left destitute— Mr Wright, son to Governor Robert Wright came to apply for the same office, and brought warm Letters of recommendation from the same persons; particularly from Genl. S. Smith the Senator; and from John Barney, M.H.R. for Baltimore. I had received however yesterday from Pleasonton, a Letter soliciting the place for Thomas M. Rodney, son of the late Caesar Rodney who has also left a numerous family scantily provided for. Milligan brought an old account against the Department of State, for two Treaty covers; supplied by him in 1819. for each of which he charged 100 dollars; and which I then refused to pay— He declined taking less than that sum; and says that he has since furnished others to the Department, at the same price which has been paid without objection— I promised to refer the case to Mr D. Brent— Watkins spoke of a Letter from Mr Clay to Mr Hammond of Cincinnati, Ohio, written last October, and to be published with a Letter of comment by Hammond, in the National Intelligencer— It states Clay’s objections against voting for Mr Crawford— I doubted the expediency of the publication at this time; believing it totally useless for Clay himself who needs no justification with the Nation at large, and who could not by any publication
publication at this time satisfy those, who are still dissatisfied— But it would bear an appearance of unkindness to Mr Crawford, who never will be a candidate again, and whom to expose now is to war with the dead— Watkins spoke also with bitterness of Wyer, who has abused him in the Washington City Gazette, and he told me of the manner in which Wyer refused the offer of going as a Messenger to England, with the appointment of Mr Rush to the Treasury Department; and afterwards resented the employment of Watkins’s son upon the same business. G. Graham came to speak of the Choctaw school fund. Has found at the Bank, the papers relating to the Stock standing in the name of P.U.S. for the Seneka’s. Mr Monroe had given him Graham while acting Secretary of War, and to his Successors a power to receive and pay over the dividends. The power passed to Mr Calhoun as his Successor, and by him was assigned to Major Van de Venter, as Chief Clerk of the Department. But part of the fund is in Stock which was redeemed last year, and not having been reinvested, the interest upon it has been lost. This shews still further the necessity of providing some regular system of accountability for the investment of the money, and the payment of the Dividends— Governour Barbour came in, while I was conversing with Graham on this subject— It was new to him— He will enquire concerning the state of the annuity to the Seneka’s— He had seen Chilly Mackintosh, and the other Creek Chiefs. They charge Crowell the Agent with having refused the Mackintosh party rations at the Council Meeting, and insinuate that he instigated the other chiefs to the murder of Mackintosh. I desired Mr Barbour to bring them to some specific charge against Crowell, which he might be called to answer— He proposes to send a trusty special sub-agent, to carry an answer to the Governor of Georgia, who threatens on the part of that State, immediate acts of violence for retaliation or protection—to inform the Governor of Georgia, that the United States never have interposed, and cannot interpose in transactions of internal feuds in an Indian tribe—that the messenger go to the upper Creeks, and inform them of the horror with which we have received the information of these outrages: to warn them against further violence; advise them to return to their homes, and give them permission to send a deputation here next winter as they have requested— I approved of these measures, but am persuaded they will be insufficient; and apprehend this massacre is only the signal for a ferocious Indian War; bursting upon us like a thunderbolt. I requested the Secretary of War to ascertain and let me know, what military force we could bring to bear immediately upon the menaced borders of Georgia— C. Bulfinch came as I had requested; and we viewed with Govr. Barbour the designs and models, for the premium. I desired Bulfinch to tell Elgar that I declined deciding which design should have the premium; believing that no one of them was entitled to it. But as I was unwilling merely upon my own opinion to decide against all the competitors, Mr Elgar might appoint three persons of taste and skill to decide, both whether the premium should be awarded to any one of the designs; and if so, to which of them. Dr Thornton and
and C. King were mentioned by me, and Coll. Bomford, by Mr Bulfinch, as suitable persons for this reference— Mr Weightman the Mayor of Washington, brought me a written opinion of Walter Jones, that four sums of ten thousand dollars, might be raised by Lottery in one year, under the Law contemplating such a Lottery, for each of four successive years. I told the Mayor I would take it into consideration. Mr D. Brent came— I gave him a list of Books that I had made out, to be purchased by Mr Rufus King, for the Department of State, and the draft of a Letter to Mr King in relation to it— Mr Clay had requested me to furnish such a list— Mr Hugh Thompson, and Dr Stewart of Baltimore, called for a Morning visit— In my daily solitary walk, I met Mr Robert Brown who stopped and informed me that he was the trustee appointed by the Creditors of Robert Easter an insolvent debtor, and that a sale would soon be made of his effects— I have a Mortgage upon his house which Brown said was more than it would sell for, and he made me several propositions concerning it. I told him he might advertise the sale at his convenience, and I would in the meantime determine what to do upon the subject.— Mrs. W. S. Smith dined with us.— Mary and Elizabeth at Mr Ramsay’s—where Mrs Monroe arrived this Evening, with Mr Gouverneur; going to New-York. symbols
17. V:15. symbols 5 symbols 6 symbols Cloudy

Watkins brought me the Letter of Mr Hammond of Cincinnati to the Editors of the National Intelligencer, and the Extracts from Clay’s Letter to him written last October stating objections to a vote for Mr Crawford— There were several erasures from the extracts: of passages which Watkins had thought it would be advisable to omit— This confirmed me in the opinion that it would be better not to publish it, at all— The passages erased were of no consequence in themselves but as they would give a handle for cavillers— Watkins gave me also a Letter from H. Niles, in behalf of T. M. Rodney with whose appointment as commercial Agent at the Havana, he wishes that his recommendation yesterday of Simonton may not interfere. Mr M’Intyre was a man of whom I had no knowledge but who came to borrow 200 dollars— I gave Mr Southard several papers for reference to the Departments both of the Treasury and the Navy. The Court of Inquiry have made a call for Documents which make it a matter for consideration whether the Correspondence between the Navy Department and him of the last year should not be laid before them— Porter’s conduct was then so dissatisfactory to President Monroe, that he declined seeing Porter, and but for his previous services would then have brought him to a Court-Martial— But as no measure was actually taken against him then it seems unfair to make
to make his conduct then a subject of censorial inquiry now— I gave Southard the opinion of Walter Jones upon the proposed City Lottery, and asked him to write to The Attorney General who is at Baltimore, asking his opinion of the legality of this quadruple Lottery and also to give me his own— On examination of the precedent cited by Jones, it does not bear him out in his argument. Southard’s first impression was like mine that the Law does not give the President the power to approve such a Lottery. The Revd. Salmon Cowles came twice for a Subscription for Alma College, at New Athens, Harrison County Ohio— Captain Bainbridge introduced a young Mr Payne, son of late Mr William Payne of Boston. He was to leave the City to-morrow Morning— Governor Barbour had further Letters from Governor Troup of Georgia; with enclosures leading to the expectation that within three days from the time when they were written a hostile incursion of Creek Indians into Georgia, was thought inevitable. Barbour had prepared an answer to Troup’s first Letter, which has now become unsuitable. Chilly Mackintosh has made written specific charges against the Agent Crowell, and presents various claims for protection and indemnity— Referring to the 8th. Article of the Treaty of Indian Springs, which contains a promise of protection, very insidiously introduced and the purport of which was certainly not considered by the Senate when they advised to the ratification of the Treaty— I directed that Crowell should be suspended from the Agency, and called to answer to the Charges of Governor Troup and of Mackintosh— In the mean time that a special temporary agent should be appointed— That General Brown should be consulted and General Gaines ordered to repair to the neighbourhood of the Creek Territory and to wait there for Instructions. No report yet from Crowell— The instant we begin to move, the want of money is felt; the means of the Executive are so limited; and the aspect of War is so menacing, that I know not how we shall avoid the necessity of calling Congress together in the midst of Summer— Rodney and Purviance both came to obtain the appointment of commercial agent at the Havana: they were both here together; Rodney with S. Pleasonton, and Purviance with D. Brent. Mountain afterwards came with T. Randall, to solicit the same office— Dr. Watkins came afterwards with Mr Southard; to ask an order upon the Navy Department, from me for the payment of about 9000 dollars, due to the Widow and Administrator, of a Mr Johnson, a Purser in the Navy, who is herself at the point of Death. The account is adjusted, and the balance due to Johnson acknowledged; but it is charged upon a contingent appropriation before 1824 which is exhausted— There is no fund from which the payment can be made; and the question is whether I could transfer the payment of it to any other appropriation— I thought I could not but Mr Southard took the papers to consult the Laws concerning transfers of appropriation, according to which I am definitively to act. Elgar the Commissioner of the public buildings was here I told him . . .
upon the designs for the tympanum of the Capitol, and mentioned to him Dr ThorntonColl. Bomford, and C. B. King the painter as persons to whom he might refer to the questions first, whether any one of the designs deserved the premium, and if anyone did, which it was— Coll. Roberdeau, brought me from the War Department a large map of Georgia. There was a heavy thunder shower, which detained me from my daily walk till Evening— The State of the atmosphere these two days, together with the prospects of Affairs, and dark anticipations, unduly affect my breath and Spirits

Handy came to tell me that he had heard L. D. Teackle was about to receive an appointment abroad; and had felt an irresistible impulse to come and tell me that his character was disreputable: and he mentioned various circumstances relating to him and much to his disadvantage. Conner brought some papers concerning the timber at the Navy Yards; and complained of having been harshly used by the Secretary to the Navy Comissioners— Governour Barbour brought the draft of a Letter to the Governor of Georgia; to be sent by Chilly Mackintosh— Crowell the Agent suspended— Genl. Gaines to be ordered to go to Milledgeville, and consult with the Governor upon the best measures for protecting the frontier of Georgia, if necessary, and the friendly Indians: to draw such troops of the U.S. there as may be necessary, of the four companies at Pensacola, and to take command of the Georgia Militia, to be called out, if required— The difficulty is to provide for the expence, for which great responsibility must be assumed, and we are to consult further. I told Rodney that he should have the agency at the Havana, and the certificate was furnished him at the Department of State— G. Sullivan came and took leave. Spoke of his visits to Mr Jefferson and Mr Madison, the latter of whom he said appeared cordially disposed to this Administration— Mr Jefferson less so; and particularly with regard to Mr Clay. Sullivan said he should pass through Worcester on his way home, and asked what he should say for me to the Governor Lincoln— I said he should give my compliments to him, and congratulations upon his election—with, my hope that he would find the Chair of Massachusetts a bed of roses, which I could assure him the Presidential Chair was not. Sullivan left the City this day, with his family— Elgar, Coll. Bomford and King came to examine the designs and models for the Tympanum, and thought none of them entitled to the premium. A Selection of the ideas from several of them, with great simplification of the design, appeared to be the most expedient course, but it would scarcely be justifiable to take ideas from designs offered for a promised premium, and to withhold all recompense. Daniel Brent brought a Note from Baron Tuyll, the Russian Minister, requesting an Audience, for which I fixed to-morrow at one O’Clock. Watkins had a Letter from T. Finley of Baltimore soliciting the Agency at the Havana. The Revd. Mr Niel is a Roman Catholic Clergyman of St. Louis, Missouri, bound to Europe in
in search of Charity. He brought me a Letter of Recommendation for a Passport, and other aid, from T. H. Benton, the Missouri Senator, and he had a subscription book, still blank, for a fund to redeem a Church at St. Louis, taken in Execution by the workmen who built it— The Revd. Mr Niel who is a “little round, fat, oily man of God,” told me there was great need of religious instruction at St. Louis. His looks were not prepossessing. Mr Southard called upon various objects depending upon the Treasury Department—particularly the providing of money to be placed at the disposal of Genl. Gaines, without appropriation—whether by Loan from the Bank U.S. or by applying to this object the appropriation made to be paid to the emigrating Indian party, which if not already paid must now be withheld— I gave Mr Southard directions for the dismission of Moses Fort, a delinquent Collector at Beaufort S.C. and for Commissions to be issued for receivers of Public monies at Edwardsville, Illinois and Cahaba, Alabama; It was past five when Mr Southard left me; and from 9 in the morning, I had not been ten minutes at a time without company. So it is almost every day— I took a walk of a quarter of an hour before dinner 4 symbols after dinner and spent the latter part of the Evening at Mr T. B. Johnson’s with Mrs Adams, Mary and Elizabeth, Mr and Mrs Frye, and Mrs W. S. Smith. Cards symbols
Signed Commission of Hardy W. Pope as Collector and Inspector Pearl-river in place of declined—

div.p: 19. V:15. symbols 9. symbols 10 symbols Summer heat and Night-gust.
Mr Baker brought me from the Department of State, a list of Books which I had made out to be ordered in England by Mr R. King, corrected some of the Books having been already procured.

With Genl. Brown I had a long Conversation, upon the prospects of a War, with the Creek Indians. He remarked upon the extreme violence of Governor Troup; but observed that an Indian war, might be an object of profitable interest to the State of Georgia. He spoke of Gaines as a very fair, honourable and virtuous man, but somewhat excitable; entertaining sentiments of strong aversion to the Indians, and perhaps liable to be influenced by some indiscreet persons, connected with him— Among the rest he mentioned his Aide de Camp Butler, who was recently with him here; a near connection of General Jackson’s, and who behaved so improperly to Mr Clay— Brown said he had written to Genl. Gaines on the subject, and hoped Mr Clay had been mistaken in the opinion that Butler had purposely withheld his hand from him in my antichamber. I said I hoped it would prove so; thinking it very unjustifiable conduct in Lieutenant Butler, if intended by him.

Baron Tuyll, the Russian Minister came at one O’Clock. Gave me thanks for the communication to him of the Instruction to Mr Middleton relating to the State of the War between Spain and her continental American ex-Colonies. He spoke in terms of high commendation of this measure; and said that without being able to anticipate, what the Emperor’s determination upon it may be; he is quite sure that it will be received and treated by him, with great consideration, and as an act equally marked by moderation, candour and friendly feeling
feeling towards him on the part of the United States. He said he was very desirous that there should be time for this measure to have its full effect, and observing in the newspapers a Proclamation of General Santa Ana, of Guatemala, for an expedition against the Island of Cuba, he hoped the Government of the United States would exercise their influence with those of South-America, to suspend any such movement at this time, the result of which might much increase the difficulties of the pacification which was so much to be desired— He also enquired if he might communicate to the Russian Ambassadors at Paris and London, Pozzo di Borgo, and Count Lieven the substance of the Instruction to Mr Middleton. It was possible especially that Mr Pozzo di Borgo, upon receiving the information, might even before the Instruction would reach St. Petersburg, give some hint, and exercise some influence at Madrid, which might prevent any counteraction there to the purpose intended by it. I answered the Baron, that I had been glad to have an opportunity of manifesting my Sentiments towards him, by the confidential communication of the Instruction to Mr Middleton— This has been sent upon the special emergency of the times, since the annihilation of the Spanish force in Peru: from a full confidence in the moderation and magnanimity of the Emperor, and from the conviction that his power might now be most efficaciously interposed to restore, and preserve the Peace of the world. It was apparent that the Spanish dominion was annihilated on the American Continents— The Castles of Callao and of San Juan d’Ulua, were the only two spots of which they retained possession; both besieged, and incapable henceforth of affording the means of offensive operations to Spain— But Cuba still remained in her possession, and was a post of annoyance both against Mexico and Colombia. Released from the necessity and occasion of employing their armed force upon their own territories, they must naturally look to Cuba, as a stronghold of their Enemy, an attack upon which by them was an essential part of their defence of themselves— But neither Mexico, nor Colombia, were desirous of atchieving the conquest of Cuba, with a view of annexing it to themselves. From its situation and the character of its population it could only prove an useless and insupportable burden to them. Neither were the United States desirous of making it a part of their confederation. But the island was at their doors; they could not suffer it to be transferred from Spain to any other European Power; nor could they willingly see it conquered either by Mexico or Columbia— These sentiments of ours were known to the Governments of those two Republics, and were not disapproved by them. We should dissuade them from the expedition against Cuba, for the present— But we must treat with them as independent Nations, and while Cuba and Porto-Rico were held by Spain, as stations from which to organize expeditions against them, we can neither demand nor expect that they should abstain from hostile enterprizes against those Islands in their turn. Cuba was to the United States an object of paramount commercial importance— The capital employed in the trade was greater than that with all the dominions of France: the tonnage employed in it nearly equal to that with Great-Britain— We were content that it should remain in its present Condition, under the dominion of Spain, but enjoying
enjoying a free trade with us. If the Emperor Alexander should present these Considerations to Spain, founded as they are upon a most important interest of Spain herself, we cannot doubt that they would prove efficacious; by preserving to Spain two Islands immensely valuable to her; by restoring general peace; and by accomplishing an arrangement adapted at once to the interests of all the European and all the American Powers— I consented that he should communicate to Pozzo di Borgo, and to Count Lieven the substance of the Instructions to Mr Middleton; but requested both for the safety of the conveyance, and to give me an opportunity of letting Mr Brown at Paris know that the Russian Ambassador there would have this information, that he would send this despatch by Mr R. King who is to sail from New-York the first of June— He readily agreed to this, and said he would communicate to me a copy of his despatches to the Ambassadors on this subject.

On leaving the Baron I found Mr Barbour the Secretary of War in my Cabinet. He had this morning received intelligence of the decease of his father at the age of 90.— The importance of the public despatches also received this morning had alone induced him to come out. He had further Letters from the Governor of Georgia, with enclosures of false and fabricated intelligence; and two Letters of 2. and 6. May from the Agent Crowell. The Little Prince, an eminent Creek Chief told Crowell that the Massacre of Mackintosh was only the Execution of a Law of the tribe, and disclaimed all intention of hostile designs against any white man— Mr Barbour had a draft of Instructions to Genl. Gaines, to which he proposed to add a Supplementary Letter, in consequence of these advices from Crowell. Major Andrew is to be sent off as a special Agent to-morrow, with a contingent power to suspend Crowell if necessary; for in his second Letter this Agent expresses an apprehension that he might be charged by his Enemies in Georgia, with being accessary to the Slaughter of Mackintosh, and most solemnly disclaims having had any knowledge of it. I thought it would therefore be a harsh measure in this state of things to suspend him positively, and might have a bad effect upon the Indians themselves, and urge them to desperation, when they might otherwise be restrained— I thought it advisable also that Gaines’s authority to act by hostile measures should be expressly limited to the protection of the Georgia frontier, or to the event that the Indians who slew Mackintosh should continue embodied and continuing their outrages upon the other party— Governor Troup’s measures have been exceedingly hasty and intemperate— symbols Mr Southard S.N.T. came in while Mr Barbour was with me, and we had consultation as to the mode of placing money at the disposal of Genl. Gaines— The sum to be limited to 100000 dollars and to be furnished by drafts on the Collector at New-York. He had some written observations of Asbury Dickins on it, which he left with me. He also read a very long Letter from Mr Wirt, who is at Baltimore, in favour of the three founderies which furnish the Ordnance, against the proposed advertisement for contracts by under-bidding. Barbour had ordered the advertisements to issue to-morrow. After Wirt’s Letter was read, and much conversation concerning it, I thought it best to suspend the advertisement for further Consideration, which Mr Barbour will order accordingly. Southard had likewise received
received an opinion of Mr. Wirt, A.G. with which his own concurs, against the Power of the President to approve the Resolution of the Washington City Corporation to raise by Lottery four Sums of 10000 dollars at once. It was near five O’Clock before I could walk out. We had company to dine. D. Brent, Mr. and Mrs Frye, Mr Harrow, Dr. Huntt, T. B. Johnson, Mrs Johnston of Louisiana, C. F. Mercer, Mr and Mrs Sigourney, Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith, Mr Southard and Dr. Watkins— Mrs Southard was unwell, and could not come— Coll. and Mrs Lawless were invited but engaged at the Baron de Mareuil’s. They were married last Evening, the Lady being the widow of the late Prussian Minister Resident, Greuhm. Mary Hellen, and Elizabeth Adams, went to the French Minister’s Evening party. Mr and Mrs Frye, Mrs Smith and Mr T. B. Johnson spent the Evening here. Stormy with Thunder showers hail and rain—
Signed Exequatur of Buchet Martigny, as French Vice Consul ad interim at Baltimore.
20. V. symbols 11. symbols 12 symbols

Governour Barbour read to me his definitive Letter to the Governor of Georgia, and his intruction to Gaines— He was to despatch Major Andrews this day. The powers to Gaines are contingent upon the continuance of outrage by the Indians— Should they have dispersed he is to assemble them in council, and urge upon them the necessity of carrying the Treaty of Indian Springs into Execution. And an explicit warning is given to the Governor of Georgia, to postpone the surveying of the Territory, a design to do which prematurely proclaimed by the Governor of Georgia, as his motive for calling a Session of the Legislature, and with the sanction of Mackintosh to the measure ostentatiously displayed, was in all probability the cause of the bloody proscription of that chief. I begin to indulge the hope that a war may yet be avoided— Mr Selden came to solicit an appointment as Navy Agent at Pensacola— He mentioned having had promises from Mr Monroe; and said he could if necessary procure a Letter of Recommendation from him; which I advised him to do, and to have filed at the Department of the Navy— Mr Hay has been several days in the City— He spoke with much concern of the disturbances among the Indians and in Georgia, and strongly expressed the opinion that the Treaty of Indian Springs ought not to have been ratified— It ought never to have been made; but nothing could have arrested the progress of this iniquity, after the Selection of two Georgians, as Commissioners for negotiating the Treaty— They concluded the Treaty directly in the face of their Instructions; but when the Treaty came here, the President could not withhold it from the Senate; and when before the Senate no one would take the invidious task of exposing its injustice— The Senate sanctioned its ratification without giving it an examination, and I had no practicable alternative but to ratify it accordingly— The Clark party in Georgia already make it a matter of public reproach against me— Mr Hay’s concern is more sympathetic— Southard brought me Wirt’s opinion, confirmed by his own, against the Power of the President
President to approve the City-Corporation Lottery Resolution— Asked about the remarks of A. Dickins on the mode of placing money at the disposal of Genl. Gaines—no decision this day. He gave me an Act and Letter of Genl. Mason, respecting the Potowmack and Ohio Canal Company. C. F. Mercer had left other papers concerning it here yesterday— There is an Act of the Legislature of Virginia, incorporating the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company—confirmed by an Act of the Legislature of Maryland—and both confirmed by an Act of Congress of 3. March 1825. ch: 54. The Act of Virginia provides that as soon as the Potowmac Company shall have assented to it the Executives of the two States and the President of the United States, shall each appoint three Commissioners to open books and receive subscriptions to the Stock of the new Company. Genl. Mason’s Letter transmitted the Corporate Act of the Potowmac Company, assenting to the new act of incorporation— Commissioners are now to be appointed. H. Shoemaker came with a Letter from R. Peters jr. and other Letters recommending Lewis Shoemaker as commercial consular Agent in at Matanzas in the place of F. Adams deceased. I postponed the appointment till authentic advices should be received of this event, which came by the mail of the day. S. Harrison Smith came for a morning visit—

Bath and Swim in the Potowmac after breakfast. John went with me to the river— Overtaken and drenched by a violent thunder shower— Occasion for changing clothes and assuming Summer raiment. Mercer came upon the business of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal— To urge the appointment of the Commissioners to open the subscription books. He had left the names of several persons whom he recommended— And I fixed to his satisfaction upon S. H. Smith of Washington, Clement Smith of Georgetown and A. J. Cazenove of Alexandria as the three— Mercer told me that Governor Barbour had mentioned to him an attack upon the Administration in the Richmond Enquirer, for the appointment of Philip C. Pendleton as judge for the western District of Virginia. The author he said was John Green, always a bitter enemy of Mr Monroe. But he said no better appointment could possibly have been made. Mr Brent brought me a draft of a despatch from Baron Tuyll to Count Lieven—written in consequence of his interview with me on Thursday, and which he had sent to the Department of State to be communicated to me— Mr Brent spoke also of the appointment of a Justice of Peace in Georgetown, and one in this City— I directed that the Commissions should be made out— Also of the Potowmack company Commissioners; and of Lewis Shoemaker, as commercial agent at Matanzas— I wrote a confidential Letter to R. King and

Mosher— Coll. J. jr. sometime private Secretary to President Monroe—called this morning to take leave— Going to Gibraltar; and thence if he can, to cruize with our Squadron in the Mediterranean for the restoration of his health— He says he is threatened with a pulmonary complaint; but his appearance is that of a man on the borders of the grave— He was however cheerful, and said he had once before, about ten years since been driven to Europe by the same complaint— I heard Little. from 2. Corinthians 5.17. “Therefore, if any man be in Christ, he is a new Creature: old things are passed away: behold all things are become new.” His object was to shew that the Unitarians, believed the application of this text to Christians of the present age, as earnestly as any other sect of Christians— I called to see Dr Thornton who is ill in bed. He has been for some months much out of health, but had apparently recovered, and was last Sunday Evening with Mrs Thornton at my house— He was very suddenly seized that same Night, and has not since left his bed— He is exceedingly reduced both by his disease and his remedies— He can scarcely speak, but retains his facetious humour, and his South-American ardour— He was very fearful that the British would cut a canal for Line of Battle and India Ships, and obtain an exclusive right of navigating for forty years. Met Dr Tucker the Treasurer at his house— Read Colman’s Sermons 10. upon human ability, and 11. upon divine influences—grace and works. Heard Baker 1. Thessalonians 5.19. “Quench not the Spirit.” He said there was a manifest awakening, among many of the members of that Church; and hoped for more. Read Johnson’s Sermon 5. On the “Miseries of Life.” Rather carelessly written; and feebly reasoned— Heard Little. 1. Peter 1.3. “Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, which according to his abundant mercy hath begotten us again unto a lively hope by the Resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead”— It was on Resurrection and immortality a subject always of deep interest, and it was treated with that temperate eloquence, which the Unitarian doctrines cannot transcend— It was one of his best discourses.
23. IV. symbols 17. symbols 18 symbols Sun-rose 4:48

Mr Randall is an inhabitant of Annapolis; father of Captain Thomas Randall of this City and of Mrs Hagner— He is on a visit here, and thanked me for the kindness I had shewn his Son— Mr George Graham brought a corrected list of Blank Land-grants which I have signed, and now remaining at the Land-Office. He says they will now begin the filling up of those Blanks. I read to him two Letters, which I had received relating to the sale of Public Lands; one from Enos Pickering, the request of which he said was impracticable and a Memorial from Alabama, praying for immediate Land-sales; upon which he said there had been much diversity of opinions, but that to preserve the public from impositions the sales there had been deferred till June 1826.— The Mayor Weightman came to receive my determination concerning the City Lottery Resolution— I declined approving it, and told him the opinion of the Attorney-General, and that of Mr Southard concurred with mine
mine that the Law did not authorise me to approve it. I gave him the Resolution, observing that I had not written my disapprobation upon it; and should not, unless the Corporation should desire that I would— I had thought they might prefer to cancel their Resolution, and pass one for a single Lottery to raise ten thousand dollars, which I could approve— Coll. Brearley came to inform me of his wish to be appointed a special Agent to examine and report upon the location beyond the Arkansas for the Creek Indians, who are to remove thither in September 1826. He assigned to me several reasons shewing the expediency of such an appointment, and mentioned some heavy expences which had been occasioned by the omission to make such an one heretofore— He spoke also of considerations personal to himself and relating to his own interest which induced him to wish for the appointment. He is now the Naval Storekeeper at the Navy-yard in this City.— A person by the name of Drain came with a petition of James Gudgeon for discharge from imprisonment— He has been confined since October last, upon a conviction for assault and battery.
Mrs Adams taken ill—confined to her bed. symbols

Mr Cassedy and his Son, are travellers, who left their home to visit some of the cities of the union, for their amusement and came to see me to gratify their curiosity. Mr Southard brought the Report of the Court of Inquiry, upon the conduct of Captain Porter which he read to me; it is the second report, & upon that part of it which had been requested by himself; is fully justificatory and commendatory of him— The testimony and documents in support of the Report are very voluminous. Mr Southard enquired, if there was any reason for detaining the Court any longer— I thought there was not—of which they were notified and adjourned without day. Mr King of the Department of State came for the Act of Virginia, incorporating the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company. Mr Brent thought the Act required that one of the Comissioners for opening the books should be an inhabitant of the City of Washington, which would have precluded the appointment of S. H. Smith; but it was not so. It is a peculiarity of this Law, that the power and the duty of the President of the United States to appoint these Commissioners is given by the Act of the Legislature of Virginia, which is confirmed by the Act of Congress, but is not printed with the Laws of the United States— Mr King brought also a Commission joint and several to Edward S. Lewis of Washington, and James Gettys of Georgetown as Justices of Peace for the County; which I signed. Mr Barbour had a private Letter from J. S. Skinner, corresponding Secretary of the Maryland agricultural Society, mentioning that in March the Society had invited me and him, and the other heads of Departments, to attend the next annual Cattle Show, and exhibition of household manufactures at a tavern four miles out of Baltimore. That
That answers had been received from all, but from him and me; at which the Society were a little hurt— That they were to meet next Saturday at his house, at which time our answers might be received; and there was an argument on the President’s attendance, to give countenance and encouragement to Agriculture— The Exhibition is to be the first and second of June— The best exhibitions on the first; and the distribution of the Premiums which they wish the President to make is on the second— Mr Barbour had not received his invitation. I had received mine, and had delayed answering under some hesitation whether to go or not. I now concluded for various reasons not to go. From Skinner’s Letter to Barbour it is apparent, that the Society wish to make the President of the United States a part of their Exhibition— To gratify this wish, I must give four days of my time; no trifle of expense, and set a precedent for being claimed as an article of exhibition at all the Cattle shows throughout the Union— From Cattle-shows to other public Meetings for purposes of utility, or exposures of public Sentiment the transition is natural and easy— Invitations to them would multiply from week to week, and every compliance would breed the necessity for numerous excuses and apologies— Finally this is no part of my duties; and some duty must be neglected to attend to it— Seest thou a man diligent in his business?— I answered Mr Skinner, declining the invitation. Governor Barbour proposes to go; and thence to the examination at West Point—to Boston—Portsmouth—and perhaps to Portland— The question about the purchases of Ordnance recurred again. I made several enquiries, as to the prices of the Articles furnished by the three founderies, with a view to comparison of prices— Govr. Barbour will have a Report made by Coll. Bomford, to-morrow— He also left with me ten Leases of Lead mines in Missouri, which have been made, and require the ratification of the President, the rent reserved is a tenth part of the lead made from the Mines—and Govr Barbour said more could not be obtained— The alternative hitherto has been total loss— The act of Congress authorizing the President, to cause these lead mines to be leased, is of 3. March 1807. U.S. Laws Vol. 4. p. 119.— Dr Waterhouse called upon me this Evening; just arrived from Cambridge— Mr T. B. Johnson was here. Mrs Adams still keeps her bed. I Bathed in the Potowmack, alone, and swam about 20 minutes—between 1. and 3. after which there were several heavy Showers; and the Evening so sultry that I could not write.

The Post-master General came to introduce Mr Sherwood who is a mail contractor for two daily mails from Utica to Albany in the State of New-York. These are not found sufficient for the wants of the people inhabiting at and between those places, and Sherwood comes to contract for a third mail— Mr Brent mentioned that Mr Salazar the Colombian Minister had received information that the commercial Treaty concluded by Mr Anderson had been ratified at Bogota, and that Salazar was in daily expectation of receiving it. In the absence of Mr Clay I authorised Mr Brent to exchange the Ratifications with Mr Salazar. Brent said

said Mr Addington had expressed a willingness that copies should be taken of the two papers which he had left with him the day before yesterday to be communicated to me— They were the Note of the Spanish Minister of foreign Affairs Zea-Bermudez, protesting against the recognition by Great-Britain of the Independence of Mexico, Colombia, and Buenos-Ayres, and the reply of the British Secretary of State Canning— I desired Mr Brent to have copies of them made for me. Captain Doane came with renewed importunities, for the appointment to command a Revenue Cutter to be built at Baltimore; and Mr Hall for a re-appointment in the Marine Corps— Mr Cameron brought a Letter of recommendation from the Governor of Pennsylvania, John Andrew Schultze, and came to obtain an appointment also in the Marine Corps. Kirby, who is paymaster at Utica, is here upon business, only for two days. Mr Cutts the second Comptroller, brought me several papers relating to a claim of D. Parker, for allowance of double rations while he was adjutant General. Mr Calhoun by various orders and at different times ordered the allowance or disallowance of them to sundry officers in a very arbitrary manner, and indulged a feeling of personal hostility to Parker, by depriving him of them, while he allowed them to other Officers of like rank, and analogous duties— Parker applied to me about it sometime since, but I could afford him no remedy. Captain Barron came merely for a visit on his passage from Philadelphia, to Norfolk to which station he has recently been removed— Captains ChaunceyCrane and Reed, the members of the late Court of Inquiry came also to take leave.— Ironside with the last biennial Register; to enquire if I had any alterations to suggest— Mr Samuel T. Anderson, brought me a Letter from Mr Southard to him asking him if he was naval Store-keeper at Pensacola, instead of answering which he applies directly to me— He states that he was promised by Mr. Munroe, through Govr Lloyd that he should have justice done him; by which he understands it as a promise that he should be appointed Navy-Agent at Pensacola— I referred him to the Secretary of the Navy, and before evening received from him another Letter of solicitation for Justice— Dr. Watkins brought me a Letter he had just received, not signed, but from D. Webster, urging the exercise of influence on my part, to secure the election of Jeremiah Mason as Senator from New-Hampshire; which I declined from a conviction that such interference would be not correct in principle, and unavailing in result—there being not the remotest chance of Mason’s election— Webster himself ought to have seen this. Dr Waterhouse came in the Evening— Going upon a visit to Mr Jefferson— Johnson Hellen came in from Rockville— There were several thunder-showers which with the continual stream of visitors through the day detained me at home— Weather at sultry Summer heat.
